Fortunately Luntz â€“ whoseÂ in-depth survey of British votersâ€™ attitudesÂ is essential reading â€“ hasnâ€™t become a sudden convert to collectivism. He simply means that the word â€˜capitalismâ€™ has so [â€¦]
The post Weekly briefing: Time for a new lexicon? appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Weekly briefing: Time for a new lexicon?

articles.author: CapX Contributor
articles.description:
Imagine you are a university vice-chancellor. Your PA gently announces a call from the cultural attachÃ©Â of a rich country not well-known for democracy, who murmurs that his government admires your institution enormously and would like to make a seriously big benefaction to it. What next? This is what happened to Cambridge last year. The UAE [â€¦]
The post Cambridge must take care, but itâ€™s well within its rights to take money from the UAE appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Cambridge must take care, but itâ€™s well within its rights to take money from the UAE

articles.author: CapX Contributor
articles.description:
As part of a recent consultation, entitled Restoring Trust in Audit and Corporate Governance, the Government is proposing a huge list of changes to audit, company law, governance and regulatory frameworks. The proposals will have a significant impact on corporate finance. My eyes rapidly dropped from BEISâ€™s monster main document of proposals to the related, [â€¦]
The post Whatâ€™s the point of the Governmentâ€™s big corporate shake-up? appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Whatâ€™s the point of the Governmentâ€™s big corporate shake-up?

articles.author: CapX Contributor
articles.description:
Gambling remains one of Britainâ€™s favourite leisure activities, and the forthcoming Gambling Act Review has provoked serious debate as to what the future of the industry looks like. To some, the Government should use the act to squeeze the industry into submission. To myself and many others, a much more nuanced approach is best.Â  Yes, [â€¦]
The post All bets are off: the Gambling Commission is unfit to oversee the future of the National Lottery appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: All bets are off: the Gambling Commission is unfit to oversee the future of the National Lottery

articles.author: Alan Lockey
articles.description:
The erasure of decades of footballing trauma from the national psyche can lead to a distorted perspective on the passage of time. Yet it is in fact just a week since a run of politically revealing by-elections was rounded off by Labourâ€™s narrow win in Batley and Spen. One should not overread the results as [â€¦]
The post Johnsonâ€™s unique political appeal is about much more than â€˜culture warsâ€™ appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Johnsonâ€™s unique political appeal is about much more than â€˜culture warsâ€™

articles.author: CapX Contributor
articles.description:
Dawn raids â€“ where enforcement officers force their way into a house, place of worship of even a care home while the occupants are still sleeping to find and detain illegal immigrants â€“ are one of the more aggressive expressions of Priti Patelâ€™s border policy. Theyâ€™re also one of the least effective. In 2019, less [â€¦]
The post Dawn raids are not the way to enforce our immigration rules appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Dawn raids are not the way to enforce our immigration rules

articles.author: CapX Contributor
articles.description:
Thereâ€™s an irony that this Sunday England will once again face an opponent from the Apennine peninsula. Football may well be coming home, but, ultimately, the notion of the mass sporting spectacle was one that the Italiansâ€™ forebears, the Romans, brought home to us long ago. After initially resisting the Roman invasion of 43AD, the [â€¦]
The post England V Italy 43AD â€“ football and the echoes of ancient history appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: England V Italy 43AD â€“ football and the echoes of ancient history

articles.author: CapX Contributor
articles.description:
Rishi Sunak is rumoured to be considering scrapping the â€˜triple lockâ€™ in order to avoid handing pensioners an 8% pay rise. The pandemic has caused a dramatic fluctuation in earnings, which could mean the Chancellor has to stump up an extra Â£3bn unless he breaks a manifesto pledge. But it shouldnâ€™t take a single statistical [â€¦]
The post Forget the triple lock, why not scrap the retirement age? appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Forget the triple lock, why not scrap the retirement age?

articles.author: CapX Contributor
articles.description:
Covid-19 has split the country by age.Â While older generations have borne the brunt of the pandemicâ€™s health effects, they were better prepared to weather the economic storm. On the other hand, younger generations face an uncertain economic outlook with potentially long-lasting changes in the jobs market and an enormous amount of personal debt. But the [â€¦]
The post How businesses can help build a more resilient generation appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: How businesses can help build a more resilient generation

articles.author: Alys Denby
articles.description:
A day after the NHS was given the George Cross, a report found that two in five maternity services in England are not safe enough for mothers and babies. So thatâ€™s a gallantry award for East Kent NHS Trust, which plead guilty to causing the â€œwholly avoidableâ€ death of baby Harry Ritchford at just seven [â€¦]
The post Not every part of the NHS deserves a medal appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Not every part of the NHS deserves a medal

articles.author: John Ashmore
articles.description:
Few people know more aboutÂ the language of politics and how to effectively communicate with the public than Frank Luntz. An award-winning political and communications consultant, pollster and pundit, Dr. Luntz has decades of experience as an election consultant and commentator on national elections all over the world. He has worked for more than 50 Fortune [â€¦]
The post The CapX Podcast: Frank Luntz on what Britain really thinks appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: The CapX Podcast: Frank Luntz on what Britain really thinks

articles.author: Sunder Katwala
articles.description:

articles.description:
The Covid pandemic has taught us all a lot about science, but itâ€™s also reminded us of some unanswered questions about how science works. Hereâ€™s one from this week: how should we think about scientistsâ€™ political views? Monday saw a perfect illustration of this debate as Good Morning Britain co-host Richard Madeley collided with UCL [â€¦]
The post Why shouldnâ€™t we ask scientists about their political beliefs? appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Why shouldnâ€™t we ask scientists about their political beliefs?

articles.author: Kristian Niemietz
articles.description:
If you are a classical liberal, a conservative, or even a centre-left social democrat who likes to argue on Twitter, you will have noticed that your views are not especially popular on that platform. The spectrum of acceptable Twitter opinion only seems to range from â€œTankiesâ€ (i.e. full-on Stalinist/Maoists) on the Left to standard Guardianistas [â€¦]
The post Unfortunately, â€˜Millennial socialismâ€™ isnâ€™t just a Twitter phenomenon appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Unfortunately, â€˜Millennial socialismâ€™ isnâ€™t just a Twitter phenomenon

articles.author: CapX Contributor
articles.description:
China and the US are in a next generation space race, and this time the ultimate prize isnâ€™t just reaching the moon. Both powers regard space as the next theatre of international security â€“ and that has worrying consequences for the UK and the world. On 17th June, a crew of Chinese astronauts landed on [â€¦]
The post China and the US race to dominate the ultimate strategic high ground: space appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: China and the US race to dominate the ultimate strategic high ground: space

articles.author: CapX Contributor
articles.description:
Inflation has been a thing of the past so long that it is easy to forget the brutal economic hardships of the 1970s, 1980s and early 1990s in the UK. Yet inflation is currently growing at its fastest rate in nearly 40 years prompting the outgoing Bank of Englandâ€™s chief economist, Andy Haldane, to warn [â€¦]
The post The spectre of inflation is haunting Britain appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: The spectre of inflation is haunting Britain

articles.author: Bill Blain
articles.description:
Nissanâ€™s announcement of a Â£1 billion Gigafactory to build lots of lithium batteries for electric vehicles is a â€œmajor vote of confidence in the UKâ€ according to Boris Johnson. He is cheering his twin goals of decarbonisation and putting the UK firmly in the lead on the â€œwe-make-more-batteries-than-youâ€ competition with Europe. Actually as a technology, [â€¦]
The post Nissanâ€™s new Gigafactory will be a monument to a dead-end technology appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Nissanâ€™s new Gigafactory will be a monument to a dead-end technology

articles.author: Henry Hill
articles.description:
To anyone who has been trying to follow the thread of the Governmentâ€™s policy on the Union, the current stand-off over the Northern Irish Protocol cannot help but be confusing. Boris Johnson is, after all, the man who cast aside his promises to resist a border in the Irish Sea in order to â€˜get Brexit [â€¦]
The post The Protocol mess stems from years of neglecting Northern Ireland appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: The Protocol mess stems from years of neglecting Northern Ireland

articles.description:
â€œI felt completely sick.â€ 63-year-old Maria Teresa Jackson recounts the moment she found out scammers had made off with Â£120,000 of her life savings. â€œI get flashbacks of certain events and that upsets me a lot.â€ She had invested in a cryptocurrency trading scheme which began as an advert on a social media site. But [â€¦]

articles.title: The global scamdemic thatâ€™s robbing people of their life savings

articles.description:
Fresh from a not particularly rousing victory in Batley and Spen, Labour are taking the fight to the Tories with a plan to â€œBuy Britishâ€Â in public sector procurement. Appearing on the Andrew Marr Show yesterday, Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves insisted her partyâ€™s plan â€œmakes economic sense and common senseâ€. Well, one out of two ainâ€™t [â€¦]
The post Labourâ€™s reheated â€˜Buy Britishâ€™ policy would leave us all worse off appeared first on CapX.
articles.title: Labourâ€™s reheated â€˜Buy Britishâ€™ policy would leave us all worse off

articles.author: Tiffany Doherty
articles.description:
Individuals with higher socioeconomic status may enjoy a longer life, but we havenâ€™t precisely pinned down all the reasons why. Disparities in lung function may help explain the lifespan gap between the poorest and richest Americans, and in todayâ€™s episode we cover a recent study on that proposed association. Â  @DrTiff_PhD
Socioeconomic Disparity and Inequality Even Extend to Breathing first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Socioeconomic Disparity and Inequality Even Extend to Breathing

articles.description:
In an effort to determine how frequently youth are exposed to alcohol advertising, researchers at the Boston University School of Public Health studied advertising data from 2013 to 2018.

articles.title: Trends in Youth Exposure to Alcohol Advertising on Cable Television, United States, 2013â€“2018

articles.description:
I have a bit of good news concerning my Combined Positive Score (CPS, although I have also seen Composite Proportion Score). The CPS is a biomarker that helps predict whether my current treatment regimen, immunotherapy, will succeed. This post will explain what the CPS is and why it matters. Immunotherapy Letâ€™s review what immunotherapy is [â€¦]
Cancer Journal â€“ The Combined Positive Score first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Cancer Journal â€“ The Combined Positive Score

articles.description:
The good news from this study is that we do not need to abandon our multi-payer system to substantially reduce administrative costs and their impact on physicians and patients.
Reducing Administrative Costs in US Health Care: Assessing Single Payer and Its Alternatives first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Reducing Administrative Costs in US Health Care: Assessing Single Payer and Its Alternatives

articles.description:
If you subscribe to TIE by email (which you can do here), a big change is coming, but you shouldnâ€™t be concerned. Here are the details: Heretofore, you received your TIE emails of posts via feedburner, which Google is discontinuing at the end of the month. Therefore, henceforth, you will receive TIE emails via MailChimp. [â€¦]
Change coming for email subscribers first appeared on The Incidental Economist.

articles.description:
Iâ€™m fortunate to work for a hospital that provides excellent disability benefits (even in Canada, not all employers do). To qualify, I needed to get a form completed by my oncologist. Cancer Journal: Citizenship in the Kingdom of Malady first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Cancer Journal: Citizenship in the Kingdom of Malady

articles.description:
Last week we covered CBD and mental health, finding that data to back up health claims are scarce and that consumer CBD products are often sketchy. In this weekâ€™s episode on CBD and other health ailments, we find that many of the same caveats apply. Â  @DrTiff_PhD
Does CBD Have Any Value as a Treatment? first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Does CBD Have Any Value as a Treatment?

articles.description:
Cannabidiol, or CBD, is one of the most well-known components of marijuana and is not psychoactive like its THC counterpart. It has been touted as a treatment for almost any mental healthÂ  Â condition you can think of, but the overall evidence for this in humans is pretty scant. Beyond that, the evidence we do have [â€¦]
Test post #2: CBD and Mental Health first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Test post #2: CBD and Mental Health

articles.description:
This is a guest post by Will Raderman (@RadWill_), Alexandra Skinner (@alexskinnermph), and Julia Raifman (@JuliaRaifman). Will Raderman is a research fellow at Boston University School of Public Health. Alexandra Skinner is a research fellow at Boston University School of Public Health. Julia Raifman is an Assistant Professor at Boston University School of Public Health. [â€¦]
Permanent expansions of government data collection will support policy innovation first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Permanent expansions of government data collection will support policy innovation

articles.author: Shang-Jin Wei
articles.description: At-risk economies may have six months or so to implement self-help measures before any sudden US monetary-policy tightening happens. They are well advised to work on making their exchange rates more flexible, reducing their reliance on foreign-currency debt, and increasing their foreign-exchange reserves.
articles.title: The Global Dangers of Rising US Inflation

articles.author: Michael R. Bloomberg
articles.description: Abundance in a zero-emissions world means no longer exploiting and wasting finite resources, but rather valuing the nature that sustains and protects us. And three upcoming United Nations summits give governments the opportunity to listen to a chorus of calls for a healthier, more resilient future.
articles.title: The Race to Sustainable Abundance

articles.author: Nancy Qian
articles.description: For decades, development aid has gone either to governments that lack the ability to administer it, or to non-government actors who essentially compete with the state. It is time for a new approach centered on a less ambitious but far more practical objective.
articles.title: What Should Development Aid Do?

articles.author: Amal de Chickera
articles.description: Today, an estimated 15 million people are stateless, and tens of millions more are at risk of losing their nationality. This leads to exclusion and deprivation in every facet of life â€“ with consequences that have become even more dire during the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.title: Statelessness in a Pandemic

articles.author: Muhammad Yunus
articles.description: With so much of â€œnormalâ€ social and economic life put on hold by the coronavirus pandemic, there is no better time to consider new approaches to development. Until we have achieved environmental, social, and economic sustainability, we as a species will be racing against the clock.
articles.title: The Pandemic Opportunity

articles.author: Peter Singer
articles.description: The way that livestock is raised and killed has long made it a legitimate matter of public concern. Now that we can see that eating red meat affects the entire planet in a manner that none of us want, it is time for governments to end their support for it.
articles.title: Beefatarians Not Wanted

articles.author: Anu Madgavkar
articles.description: The behavioral changes that persist after the pandemic will offer new business opportunities for firms that carefully assess consumer, industry, and regulatory trends. And policymakers can help the world to boost productivity by extending and improving digital infrastructure and ensuring universal access to it.
articles.title: The Stickiness of Pandemic-Driven Economic Behavior

articles.author: Nancy Qian
articles.title: Back to Health: Nancy Qian

articles.author: Ilona SzabÃ³
articles.description: Although the COVID-19 pandemic has raised our awareness of other environmental threats like climate change, the destruction of the Amazon, one of the planet's most important climate stabilizers, continues to accelerate. Reversing this dangerous trend will require urgent reforms, underpinned by an entirely new mindset.
articles.title: Where Humanityâ€™s Future Will Be Decided

articles.author: David Miliband
articles.title: Back to Health: David Miliband

articles.author: Bill Emmott
articles.description: A growing chorus is calling for the long-awaited Tokyo Olympics to be canceled, even though the facts on the ground leave Japanese authorities with no sound reason to do so. The only thing that will stop the event now is a no-show by all of the athletes themselves.
articles.title: The Tokyo Games Will Go on

articles.author: Carl Manlan
articles.title: Back to Health: Carl Manlan

articles.author: Werner Hoyer
articles.title: Back to Health: Werner Hoyer

articles.author: Julia Gillard
articles.title: Back to Health: Julia Gillard

articles.author: Nicole Pope
articles.description: While media capture occurs in the best of times, a crisis creates opportunities to act even more brazenly to assert control over the information to which people are exposed. During the coronavirus pandemic, both repressive governments and Big Tech behemoths have seized these opportunities.
articles.title: Media Capture Under Cover of COVID

articles.author: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
articles.title: Back to Health: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

articles.author: Ed Araral
articles.description: Given the current trajectory of climate change, it is crucial that initial steps by the United States and the European Union to introduce carbon border taxes are successful. That will require policymakers to adhere to the essential principles that should govern such levies.
articles.title: The Case for Carbon Import Taxes

articles.author: Dani Rodrik
articles.description: Just as the pandemic was gathering pace in early 2020, French President Emmanuel Macron set up an international commission of economists to assess longer-term challenges and make policy proposals. While some of the recommendations are specific to France, many (if not most) are relevant to other advanced economies as well.
articles.title: Inequality and the Macron Commission

articles.author: Tom Frieden
articles.title: Back to Health: Tom Frieden

articles.author: PS Commentators
articles.description: As US and NATO troops prepare to leave Afghanistan by mid-July and the Taliban make rapid territorial gains, the outlook for the countryâ€™s long-suffering people is becoming bleaker by the day. The withdrawal is also likely to undermine regional security, embolden Islamist militants, and damage Americaâ€™s already shaky international standing.
articles.title: Afghanistan on the Brink

articles.author: Sally C. Davies
articles.title: Back to Health: Sally C. Davies

articles.author: Gro Harlem Brundtland
articles.title: Back to Health: Gro Harlem Brundtland

articles.author: Vera Songwe
articles.description: If Africa emerges from COVID-19 with old inequalities unaddressed and new opportunities unrealized, its policymakers will have failed. If they recognize that a better normal is possible, and act boldly to make it a reality, the continent will at least have something to show for the suffering of the past year.
articles.title: A Better Normal for Africa

articles.author: Koketso Moeti
articles.description: Societies must address the distribution of political and economic power that drives efforts to use digital technologies for repressive ends. Otherwise, governments and corporations will continue to diminish digital citizenship to enhance their own powers or advance their private interests.
articles.title: The Battle for Civic Space in the Digital Age

articles.author: SÅ‚awomir Sierakowski
articles.description: By reclaiming the leadership of Poland's liberal center-right party, former European Council President Donald Tusk has shaken up the Polish political scene and cast a shadow over some of its younger rising stars. To succeed, he will need to show that the Brussels technocracy didn't rub off on him.
articles.title: Donald Tusk Comes Home

articles.author: Mark Malloch-Brown
articles.description: For decades, democracy and human-rights advocates have operated on the assumption that a growing number of governments around the world were embracing freedom and its rules and norms. But the recent sharp reversal of a generation of progress is forcing advocates and activists to reconsider their models of change.
articles.title: The Fight for Open Societies Begins Again

articles.author: Agnes Binagwaho
articles.title: Back to Health: Agnes Binagwaho

articles.author: Seth Berkley
articles.title: Back to Health: Seth Berkley

articles.author: Ann Aerts
articles.title: Back to Health: Ann Aerts

articles.author: Jeffrey D. Sachs
articles.description: It is imperative that the G20 finance ministers' meeting in Venice this week act to provide the COVID-19 vaccines needed to achieve worldwide comprehensive adult immunization by early 2022. Given current production, this should not be a problem, so long as a global plan is quickly implemented.
articles.title: The G20 Must Act Now to Vaccinate the World

articles.author: Joseph S. Nye, Jr.
articles.description: Even if formal cybersecurity treaties are unworkable, it may still be possible to set limits on certain types of civilian targets, and to negotiate rough rules of the road. Whether US President Joe Biden succeeded in launching such a process at his meeting last month with Russian President Vladimir Putin may become clear soon.
articles.title: What Did Biden Achieve in Geneva?

articles.author: Christopher J.L. Murray
articles.description: The COVID-19 crisis is far from over; in many countries, it is getting worse. By investing in digital technologies now and publishing anonymized data online, policymakers can strengthen their response to the ongoing pandemic, and act quickly when another public-health threat appears.
articles.title: The Public-Health Data Systems We Need

articles.author: JosÃ© Antonio Ocampo
articles.description: The recent agreement by 131 countries to reform international corporate taxation is not the end of the road. But to bring about a more equitable outcome, developing countries must now push for a higher global minimum tax rate and a bigger reallocation of taxing rights, and refuse mandatory arbitration.
articles.title: How to Secure a Fairer Global Tax Deal

articles.author: Swee Kheng Khor
articles.description: The post-pandemic rebuilding period must feature ambitious investments in the physical, organizational, and social infrastructure needed to ensure universal health coverage. Governments have a historic opportunity to place health at the center of all policymaking, where it belongs.
articles.title: A Health New Deal

articles.author: Daron Acemoglu
articles.description: While the risk of sustained US inflation should not be ignored, nor should it cloud our view of what is really at stake in the current post-pandemic economy. American democracy is in trouble, and a robust, inclusive government-led recovery may offer the last best chance of putting it on a sounder footing.
articles.title: The Real Inflation Risk

articles.author: Djoomart Otorbaev
articles.description: With US and NATO troops on their way out and the Taliban making rapid territorial gains, Russia, China, and Central Asian governments are increasingly worried about what a destabilized Afghanistan will mean for the wider region. While all hope is not lost, the outlook is becoming bleaker by the day.
articles.title: If Afghanistan Falls

articles.author: Muhammad Hamid Zaman
articles.description: Now that COVID-19 has illustrated the destruction that can be wrought by a single virus, there is no longer any excuse for delay in tackling the growing threat posed by antimicrobial resistance. There is still time to prevent a worst-case scenario, but the window is closing fast.
articles.title: Learning from COVID to Fight Drug-Resistant Disease

articles.author: Mohamed A. El-Erian
articles.description: As the global economy emerges from the COVID-19 shock, systemically important central banks are faced with the unenviable task of deciding when and how quickly to phase out extraordinary stimulus measures. While there is no easy answer, there are clear criteria for maintaining policy credibility.
articles.title: Central Banking, Fast and Slow

articles.author: Rana Mitter
articles.description: The Communist Party of China, founded a century ago, has been in power for more than seven decades â€“ and it has big plans for the future. What do those plans entail, and is the Party still strong enough to implement them?
articles.title: The Communist Party of China at 100

articles.author: Melvyn B. Krauss
articles.description: Notwithstanding the predictable howls of protest from some Europeans, US President Joe Biden, French President Emmanuel Macron, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel are right to seek a thawing of ties with Russian President Vladimir Putin. If the main global threat is China, Putin has several compelling reasons to play ball.
articles.title: Joe Bidenâ€™s Nixon Strategy

articles.author: Joseph E. Stiglitz
articles.description: Under existing tax rules, multinational firms can escape paying their fair share of taxes by booking their income in low-tax jurisdictions, or by moving some parts of their business to these jurisdictions. Will proposed reforms deliver on their promise to boost government revenues, especially in developing countries?
articles.title: The Global Tax Devil Is in the Details

articles.author: Ludovic Subran
articles.description: What European households do with the cash buffers they have built up during the pandemic could have good, bad, or ugly consequences. The best option is for policymakers to help channel these savings into long-term investments that support the continentâ€™s green and digital transformations.
articles.title: How to Use Europeâ€™s Excess Savings

articles.author: Mari Pangestu
articles.description: Nowadays, advocates of protectionism increasingly base their arguments on tradeâ€™s adverse distributional consequences. But governments must remember that the potential benefits of trade are far greater, provided they can put in place policies that deliver them more equitably.
articles.title: Making Trade Work for Everyone
